Geothermal gradient.Description: The geothermal gradient is directly proportional to the heat flow, which is the amount of heat transferred per unit of time through a unit area.
The geothermal gradient determines the rate at which temperature changes with depth in the Earth's subsurface, known as the temperature gradient.
The geothermal gradient is influenced by the thermal conductivity of the rocks and fluids in the subsurface, which determines how easily heat can be transferred.

The geothermal gradient is used to harness geothermal energy, which is the heat energy stored beneath the Earth's surface that can be converted into electricity or used for heating and cooling purposes.
